title: Esaala PV System
description:
Esa’ala District, located in Milne Bay Province, is a scenic area known for its beauty. It comprises three
local-level governments: Dobu Rural, Duau Rural, and West Ferguson Rural. The district has a population of 54,467 individuals distributed among 11,570 households across the
three LLGs. The National Energy Authority (NEA) has conducted a feasibility of the area to determine the energy sources available in the district for off-grid electrification. This initiative aligns with the government's Energy Vision 2030, which aims to provide 70% of households with access to clean and reliable energy. This report covers the study conducted by the projects team for the possible 150kW solar system at Esa’ala station.

title: Hawa PV system
description:
The National Energy Authority has recently conducted a feasibility study at the Hawa CIS Centre in Tari, Hela Province. This project involves a 1 MW PV system combined with a Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) that will be connected to the grid supplied by PPL in Tari Town.

The site at Hawa CIS Centre is on state land, which helps to reduce land-related issues and streamline the project implementation. Attached are pictures of NEA officers working with local community members and the primary location of the PV setup, highlighting the collaboration and progress made toward bringing cleaner, reliable energy to the area.

title: Baluan Solar PV Projects
description:
The Baluan Island solar PV mini-grid project is a significant initiative of the National Energy Authority (NEA), in collaboration with the Baluan Development Association, to electrify remote, off-grid communities.  This project signifies the determination and benchmark approach that demonstrates NEA's commitments to the government's ambitious targets of 70% electricity accessibility before 2030.  The project focusses on generation infrastructure and is currently 100% complete, delivering 100 kilowatts of solar electricity and a 215-kwh battery energy storage system.  This clean and reliable system will serve over 300 households, schools, and local health clinics, reducing reliance on expensive petroleum products and biomass wood. 

Despite the hard logistics, volcanic terrain, and poor communications infrastructure, the project team maintained tremendous momentum and commitment, completing the project on time and recently commissioning it on September 9, 2025.  This project is regarded as NEA’s pilot project, and it is intended to serve as a milestone project for the implementation of similar projects in other off-grid areas of PNG.
